If we take as example the fourth stanza of the poem "A mal estrany es la pena estranya" by Ausiàs March ("Envers alguns aço miracle par,\ mas si·ns membram de Arnau Daniell\ e de aquells que la terra·ls es vel, \ sabrem Amor vers nos que pot mostrar.\ Cella que am en egual de la vida, \ mostre ’vorrir en fets y en continent:\ quant li so prop, e d’ella sbayment,\ ab continent de aver l’avorrida.") we can use an altRhymeScheme which uses capitalisation to indicate femenine rhymes: abbaCddC.
pdp:altRhymeScheme.label: alt rhyme scheme

pdp:altSyllabicMetricalLength.comment:
Alternative syllabic metrical schemes (e.g. long lines with caesura opposite to short lines).

If we consider, for instance, the second line of the poem "Te recuerdo como eras en el último otoño" by Pablo Neruda, that is, "Eras la boina gris y el corazón en calma", this line has an altCountingMetricalScheme considering a caesura after "gris". As a result, altCountingMetricalScheme would be 7+7= 14, instead of 15.
pdp:altSyllabicMetricalLength.label: alt syllabic metrical length

pdp:before.comment: This property relates a Punctuation List with its proceeding Word in a Line.
pdp:before.label: before

pdp:clausula.comment:
The categorisation of the item according to the rhythmic ending of a line  determined by the number of unstressed syllables following the last stressed one. This property is both valid for accentual and syllabic versification, so possible values include: masculine (zero syllables), femenine (one), dactylic, proparoxitone, etc.

For example, if we consider the final foot of the line from sonnet I by Shakespeare "From fairest creatures we desire increase", namely "|increase|, the clausula is: masculine.
pdp:clausula.label: clausula

pdp:clausulaScheme.comment:
Pattern of clausulae, that is, the ending of a line determined by the number of unstressed syllables following the last stressed one.

For example, if we consider the second stanza from the poem "Acaso..." by Antonio Machado: "Brotaban verdes hojas \ de las hinchadas yemas del ramaje, \ y flores amarillas, blancas, rojas, /\alegraban la mancha del paisaje."the clausulaScheme is: 4 feminine endings.
pdp:clausulaScheme.label: clausula scheme

pdp:clausulaSchemeType.comment:
Categorisation of the stanza according to the distribution of clausulae/gender of rhymes (eg. “classic”, “heterogonique”, etc.).

For example, if we consider the first stanza of the sonnet I of Canzoniere by Petrarca, namely: "Voi ch’ascoltate in rime sparse il suono/ di quei sospiri ond’io nudriva ’l core / in sul mio primo giovenile errore/ quand’era in parte altr’uom da quel ch’i’ sono" clausulaSchemeType is "Feminine rhyme".
pdp:clausulaSchemeType.label: clausula scheme type

pdp:coda.comment:
Sound or sounds that follow the nucleus.

For example in the word "mar" in Spanish, the coda of the syllable is "r".
pdp:coda.label: coda

pdp:content.comment: Full textual content of a structural element (Redaction, Line, Stanza, Word or Syllable)
pdp:content.label: content

pdp:employedTechnique.comment: Indicates which methodology or analytical technique has been applied to perform the scansion.
pdp:employedTechnique.label: employed technique

pdp:employs.comment:
This propery points to a Symbol used in metrical notation being defined.

For example, if we consider the LinePattern "-+-+-+-+-+" of the line "From fairest creatures we desire increase," from the first sonnet by Shakespeare, the MetricalEncoding employs the Symbol "+" to mark a stressed syllable or metrical position.
pdp:employs.label: employs

pdp:ending.comment:
Contents from the last stressed vowel of the rhyme to its end.

For instance, if we consider the rhyme word "vida" from the poem "Morir soñando" by Unamuno, ending is "ida".
pdp:ending.label: ending

pdp:feetType.comment:
Categorisation of the stanza or line according to the type of feet.

For example, if we consider the first line of the sonnet I by Shakespeare "From fairest creatures we desire increase", feetType is "iamb".
pdp:feetType.label: feet type

pdp:finalConsonant.comment:
Last consonant of rhyming word.

For example, if we consider the rhyming word "infinito" in the poem by Quevedo "A un hombre de gran nariz", which rhymes with "frito", the final consonant of the rhyming word is "t".
pdp:finalConsonant.label: final consonant

pdp:firstFoot.comment:
This property points to the first Foot of the line.

For example, if we consider the first line of the sonnet I by Shakespeare "From fairest creatures we desire increase", this has |from fai| as first foot.
pdp:firstFoot.label: first foot

pdp:firstFootOf.comment:
This property points to the LinePattern whose feet description begins with the current item under analysis.

For example, if we consider the first line of the sonnet I by Shakespeare "From fairest creatures we desire increase", |from fai| is its first foot.
pdp:firstFootOf.label: first foot of

pdp:firstGrammaticalSyllable.comment:
This property points to the first Syllable of a Word.

For instance, the first syllable of the word "derrota" is "der".
pdp:firstGrammaticalSyllable.label: first grammatical syllable

pdp:firstGrammaticalSyllableOf.comment:
This property points to an instance of Word of which a given Syllable is its first element.

For example, "ar" isFirstSyllable of the word "árbol".
pdp:firstGrammaticalSyllableOf.label: first grammatical syllable of

pdp:firstHemistich.comment:
This property points to the first division of a Line (an instance of Line) that forms  the first hemistich.

For example, if we consider the line "Sous le flambeau d’Amour, des éternelles nuits" from the sonnet "Afin que pour jamais une marque demeure" by Jean Antoine de Baïf, the "firstHemistich" of the line is "Sous le flambeau d'Amour".
pdp:firstHemistich.label: first hemistich

pdp:firstLine.comment:
This property points to the first Line which forms part of a given Line List.

For example, if we consider the second stanza of the poem "Calle de Arrabal" by Dámaso Alonso (i.e. "A un lado, hay un calvero de solares/ en frente, están las casas alineadas/ porque esperan que de un momento a otro/ la Primavera pasará"), the first line is "A un lado, hay un calvero de solares".
pdp:firstLine.label: first line

pdp:firstLineOf.comment:
This property points to the Line List of which the current Line under analysis is its first item.

For example, "Voi ch'ascoltate in rime sparse il suono" is the first line of the first stanza of the first sonnet of the "Canzoniere" by Francesco Petrarca.
pdp:firstLineOf.label: first line of

pdp:firstMora.comment:
This property points to the firt unit in which the foot is divided (an instance of FootDivision).

For example, if we consider the first foot of the first line of the sonnet I by Shakespeare "From fairest creatures we desire increase", namely |from fai|, this foot has "from" has its first unit.
pdp:firstMora.label: first mora

pdp:firstMoraOf.comment:
This property points to the Foot that contains the item at hand as its first element.

For example, if we consider the first foot of the first line of the sonnet I by Shakespeare "From fairest creatures we desire increase", namely |from fai|, its first unit  is "from".
pdp:firstMoraOf.label: first mora of

pdp:firstPunctuation.comment: This property points to the first Punctuation which forms part of a given Punctuation List.
pdp:firstPunctuation.label: first punctuation

pdp:firstPunctuationOf.comment: This property points to the Punctuation List for which a given Punctuation is its first element.
pdp:firstPunctuationOf.label: first punctuation of

pdp:firstStanza.comment:
This property points to the first Stanza which forms part of a given Stanza List.

For example, the poem "Poema 20" by Pablo Neruda has as first stanza "Puedo escribir los versos más tristes esta noche. / Escribir, por ejemplo: "―La noche esta estrellada, / y tiritan, azules, los astros, a lo lejos".
pdp:firstStanza.label: first stanza

pdp:firstStanzaOf.comment:
This property points to the Stanza List of which the current Stanza under analysis is its first line grouping.

For example, "Señor Don Juan, quedito, que me enfado:/ besar la mano es mucho atrevimiento; / abrazarme... no, Juan, no lo consiento.  / Cosquillas... ay Juanito... ¿y el pecado?" is the first stanza of the poem "El mismo" by Tomás de Iriarte.
pdp:firstStanzaOf.label: first stanza of

pdp:firstWord.comment:
This property points to the first Word of a given Line.

For example, "voi" is the first token of the line "Voi ch'ascoltate in rime sparse il suono" from the first sonnet of the "Canzoniere" by Francesco Petrarca.
pdp:firstWord.label: first word

pdp:firstWordOf.comment:
This property points to an instance of Line of which a given Word is its first element.

For example, if we consider the fifth stanza of the poem "Ho bisogno di silenzio" by Alda Merini, "Chi di parole da me ne ha avute tante" is the first token.
pdp:firstWordOf.label: first word of

pdp:footType.comment:
Type of foot (e.g. iamb).

For example, if we consider the final foot of the verse from sonnet I by Shakespeare "From fairest creatures we desire increase", namely "|increase|, footType is "iamb".
pdp:footType.label: foot type

pdp:grammaticalStressPattern.comment:
Pattern based on disposition of the expected stresses according to grammar rules. This includes the distribution of weak and strong positions.

For instance, if we consider the line "Piedra soy en sufrir pena y cuidado" from the homonym poem by Quevedo, grammaticalStressPattern is "+-+--++---+-" (while the metrical pattern would be +-+--+--+-, e.g. in the grammatical pattern both "sufrir" and "pena" have a stressed syllables, while in the metrical pattern "sufrir" is not stressed).
pdp:grammaticalStressPattern.label: grammatical stress pattern

pdp:grammaticalSyllable.comment: Syllable of a Word considered as list
pdp:grammaticalSyllable.label: grammatical syllable

pdp:grammaticalSyllableList.comment:
This property refers to the Word a given Syllable belongs to.

For example, the syllable "ma" belongs to the word "Lágrima".
pdp:grammaticalSyllableList.label: grammatical syllable list

pdp:grammaticalSyllableNumber.comment:
Position of the Syllable in the Word 

Eg.: 3/4 (= third syllable in a four-syllable word).
For example, in the Spanish word "recordar", the syllable "cor" is the second syllable of the word, so this field should be filled with 2/3.
pdp:grammaticalSyllableNumber.label: gramamtical syllable number

pdp:hasAnacrusis.comment:
If the line has one or more unstressed syllables at the beginning of a line of verse, before the reckoning of the normal meter begins.

For instance, if we consider the line "El que alaba la vida de la Corte" from the sonnet by Cristóbal de Mesa, has Anacrusis is "Yes".
pdp:hasAnacrusis.label: has anacrusis

pdp:hasCaesura.comment:
Whether it contains any lines with a pause/break near its middle.

If we consider, for example, the line "Suspiros y risas, colores y notas.", from the first of the "Rimas" by Bécquer, hasCaesura is negative because the line has no caesura.
pdp:hasCaesura.label: has caesura

pdp:hasLineList.comment: This property points to the Line List that conforms a Redaction.
pdp:hasLineList.label: has line list

pdp:hasPunctuationList.comment: This property points to the Punctuation List containing the punctuations present in a Line.
pdp:hasPunctuationList.label: has punctuation list

pdp:hasRefrain.comment:
Whether the work has a refrain.

For instance, if we consider the poem "Señora de hermosura" by Juan del Encina, hasRefrain would be affirmative, since it has a refrain.
pdp:hasRefrain.label: has refrain

pdp:hasRhymingWord.comment:
This property points to the instance of Word for a further linguistic analysis/division by words.

For example, the line "From fairest creatures we desire increase," from the first sonnet by Shakespeare has "increase" as rhyming word.
pdp:hasRhymingWord.label: has rhyming word

pdp:hasStanzaList.comment: This property points to the Stanza List that conforms a Redaction.
pdp:hasStanzaList.label: has stanza list

pdp:hasStartingLine.comment: This property points to the lines (instance of Line) or word (instance of Word) which contains the current item under analysis
pdp:hasStartingLine.label: has starting line

pdp:initialPhonemesPattern.comment:
Initial phonemes of each word in a line, in alphabetical order to show sound repetitions.

If we consider, for example, the line "Suspiros y risas, colores y notas.", from the first of the "Rimas" by Bécquer, initialPhonemesPattern is: [k ii n r s].
pdp:initialPhonemesPattern.label: initial phonemes pattern

pdp:initialPhonemesPatternByManner.comment:
Initial phonemes of each word in a line represented by manner, in alphabetical order to show sound repetitions.

If we consider, for example, the line "Suspiros y risas, colores y notas.", from the first of the "Rimas" by Bécquer, initialPhonemesPatternByManner is: fricative, front vowel, front vowel, stop, stop.
pdp:initialPhonemesPatternByManner.label: initial phonemes pattern by manner

pdp:interStrophicRelations.comment:
Type of technique used to related stanzas by the repetition of sounds.

For instance, the tercets of the Sonnet XI by Garcilaso are "tercetos encadenados", therefore their interStrophicRelations is "rhyme: terza rima".
pdp:interStrophicRelations.label: inter strophic relations

pdp:isCallOf.comment:
This property points to a previous Word (call) that rhymes with the current instance of Word.

For example, "escriba" is call of "arriba", if we consider the lines "Érase un elefante boca arriba,/
Érase una nariz sayón y escriba" from the poem "A un hombre de gran nariz" by Quevedo.
pdp:isCallOf.label: is call of

pdp:isCallWordIn.comment: This property relates a word with a rhyme match in which acts as the call word

pdp:isCatalectic.comment:
Whether the instance at hand is the last foot of the line or hemistich and is lacking one syllable.

If we consider, for instance, the foot "shed" of the line "Stood a lowly cattle shed" from the poem "Once in Royal David's city" by Cecil Frances Alexander, isCatalectic is "Yes" because the foot lacks one syllable. In fact, the line would be expected to be of eight syllables, as the previous line, and instead has one syllable missing. Compare the two lines: "Once in Royal David's city" (8 syllables) / "Stood a lowly cattle shed," (7 syllables).
pdp:isCatalectic.label: is catalectic

pdp:isEchoOf.comment:
This property points to a following Word (echo) that that rhymes with the current instance of Word.

For example, "arriba" is echo of "escriba", if we consider the lines "Érase un elefante boca arriba,/ Érase una nariz sayón y escriba," from the poem "A un hombre de gran nariz" by Quevedo.
pdp:isEchoOf.label: is echo of

pdp:isEchoWordIn.comment: This property relates a word with a rhyme match in which acts as the echo word

pdp:isEmployedIn.comment:
This property points to the instance of MetricalEncoding that employs the item at hand.

For example, if we consider the LinePattern "-+-+-+-+-+" of the line "From fairest creatures we desire increase," from the first sonnet by Shakespeare,the Symbol "+", for example, isEmployed in the MetricalEncoding to indicate stressed syllable.
pdp:isEmployedIn.label: is employed in

pdp:isEncodingUsedBy.comment:
This property points to an instance of LinePattern, StanzaPattern or WorkPattern which uses the convention defined in the current instance of MetricalEncoding.

For example, if we consider the LinePattern "-+-+-+-+-+" of the line "From fairest creatures we desire increase," from the first sonnet by Shakespeare, In the first line, the MetricalEncoding using "+" and "-" symbols for stressed and unstressed syllables, is used for containing the information of the pattern.
pdp:isEncodingUsedBy.label: is encoding used by

pdp:isHypermetre.comment:
It has one or more syllables in addition to those found in a standard metrical unit or line of verse.

For instance, if we consider the line "intorno la croce." from the poem "La figlia maggiore" by Pascoli, isHypermetre is "Yes" because the line should have five syllables and instead has six syllables.
pdp:isHypermetre.label: is hypermetre

pdp:isHypermetrical.comment:
Whether the instance at hand is the last foot of the line or hemistich and it contains extra syllables.

If we consider, for instance, the foot "From fai" in the line "From fairest creatures we desire increase," from the first sonnet by Shakespeare, isHypermetrical is "No" because that foot is part of the metrical pattern of the line: from FAI | rest CREA | tures WE | deSIRE | inCREASE.
pdp:isHypermetrical.label: is hypermetrical

pdp:isHypometre.comment:
It has one or more syllables less than to those found in a standard metrical unit or line of verse.

For instance, if we consider the line "e benedico quel dolce varco" from the sonnet "Sonecto d’amore di misser Guliermo maramauro de Napoli" by Marmaldo, isHypometre is "Yes"  because the line is one syllable shorter (i.e. 9 syllables) than the other lines in the poems which are all hendecasyllables. This can be observed by comparing the syllable length of the surrounding lines: "Io benedico il duro ferro e l’arco (10) / col qual mi fo passato in prima il core, (10)/ e sempre benedico e lodo Amore (10)/ che m’à del suo piacer si forte carco; (10)/ e benedico quel dolce varco (9)".
pdp:isHypometre.label: is hypometre

pdp:isInflectedForm.comment:
This property points to the lemma of a Word.

For example, in the poem "Rojo Sol, que con hacha luminosa" by Fernando de Herrera, the word "luminosa" is inflected from the lemma "luminoso".
pdp:isInflectedForm.label: inflected form

pdp:isIrregular.comment:
Whether in comparison to the other lines, the current foot breaks a regular pattern.

If we consider, for instance, the first foot of the line "Pity the world, or else this glutton be," from the first sonnet by Shakespeare, isIrregular is "Yes" because the sonnet is in iambic pentameters but the first foot of this line, namely "Pity", is a trochee. The metrical scansion of the line is: PIty | the WORLD | or ELSE | this GLUT | ton Be.
pdp:isIrregular.label: is irregular

pdp:isIsometric.comment:
Whether the work is monometric, that is, if all lines have the same metrical analysis.

If we consider, for example, the sonnet III from the "Canzoniere" by Petrarca, isIsometric is "Yes" because all lines are hendecasyllables, hence, they have the same metrical analysis.
pdp:isIsometric.label: is isometric

pdp:isIsostrophic.comment:
Whether all stanzas are metrically equivalent.

If we consider for example the poem "Canción de otoño en primavera" by Rubén Darío, isIsostrophic is "Yes" because all stanzas of the poem have the same length and the same metrical characteristics.
pdp:isIsostrophic.label: is isotrophic

pdp:isLemmaOf.comment:
This property points to one of the inflected forms (an instance of Word) of the current headword (the Word at hand).

For example, "tampoco" isLemma in the line "Si no eres par, tampoco le has tenido" from the sonnet "Orlando Furioso a Don Quijote de la Mancha" by Miguel Cervantes.
pdp:isLemmaOf.label: is lemma of

pdp:isLineListOf.comment: This property relates a Line List with the Redaction it breaks down into lines.
pdp:isLineListOf.label: is line list of

pdp:isMetricStanza.comment:
If Stanza is a metrical unit, then this should be True. Otherwise (e.g. a section, a lai, a refrain, etc) it should be set to False.

If we consider, for example, the first stanza of the poem "Caracola" by Federico García Lorca, this property would be False because that stanza is a refrain, hence, it does not have a specific metrical scheme.
pdp:isMetricStanza.label: is metric stanza

pdp:isPunctuationListOf.comment: This property relates a Punctuation List with the Line that presents the punctuations.
pdp:isPunctuationListOf.label: is punctuation list of

pdp:isRefrain.comment:
Whether a Line contains or is part of a refrain.

If we consider, for example, the first stanza of the poem "Caracola" by Federico Garcia Lorca, "iSNotMetricStanza" would be True because that stanza is a refrain.
pdp:isRefrain.label: is refrain

pdp:isRegular.comment:
Regular metrics.

For example, if we take as example the poem "Osé y temí mas pudo la osadía" by Fernando de Herrera, LinePattern isRegular since it is a sonnet and all the lines are hendecasyllables.
pdp:isRegular.label: is regular

pdp:isRhymingWordIn.comment:
This property points to the instance of Rhyme that contains the item at hand as its rhyme word.

For example, if we consider the poem "Elegía a Ramón Sijé" by Miguel Hernández, in the first line, the word "hortelano" isRhymeWord. "Hortelano" rhymes with "temprano" in the third line.
pdp:isRhymingWordIn.label: is rhyming word in

pdp:isStanzaListOf.comment: This property relates a given Stanza List with the Redaction it breaks down into stanzas.
pdp:isStanzaListOf.label: is stanza list of

pdp:isStressed.comment:
If the syllable has accent.

For example, if we take the syllable "-ñar" word "soñar" in the line "Soñar la muerte no es matar el sueño" from the poem "Morir soñando" by Unamuno, isStressed is "Yes".
pdp:isStressed.label: is stressed

pdp:isUnissonant.comment:
Whether all stanzas have the same rhyme.

If we take as example the poem "Cortesamen vuoill comensar" by the trobador Marcabru, isUnissonant is true, since all the stanzas have the same rhyme.
pdp:isUnissonant.label: is unissonant

pdp:isUsedRedactionIn.comment: This property points to a cultural product (Intertextuality) which was based on the work under analysis
pdp:isUsedRedactionIn.label: is used redaction in

pdp:isUsedSourceIn.comment: This property points to the text under analysis (Redaction) from which the current cultural product has derived
pdp:isUsedSourceIn.label: is used source in

pdp:isWordAnalysedBy.comment: This property relates a word with the analytical units that analyse it
pdp:isWordAnalysedBy.label: is word analysed by

pdp:lastGrammaticalSyllable.comment:
This property points to the last Syllable which forms part of a given Word.

For example, if we consider the word "amor", the last syllable is "mor".
pdp:lastGrammaticalSyllable.label: last grammatical syllable

pdp:lastGrammaticalSyllableOf.comment:
This property points to Word of which the current Syllable under analysis is its last item.

For example, "bla" is the last syllable of the word "niebla".
pdp:lastGrammaticalSyllableOf.label: last grammatical syllable of

pdp:lastLine.comment:
This property points to the last Line which forms part of a given Line List.

For example, for the poem "Fábula de Polifemo y Galatea", last line would be "yerno lo saludó, lo aclamó río".
pdp:lastLine.label: last line

pdp:lastLineOf.comment:
This property points to the Line List of which the current Line under analysis is its last item.

For example, "Attaccato alla vita" is the last line of the poem "Veglia" by Giuseppe Ungaretti.
pdp:lastLineOf.label: last line of

pdp:lastPunctuation.comment: This property points to the last Punctuation which forms part of a given Punctuation List.
pdp:lastPunctuation.label: last punctuation

pdp:lastPunctuationOf.comment: This property points to the Punctuation List for which a given Punctuation is its last element.
pdp:lastPunctuationOf.label: last punctuation of

pdp:lastStanza.comment:
This property points to the last Stanza which forms part of the current Stanza List.

For example, The last stanza of el poema "Diamante" by Federico García Lorca is "Se agitan en mi recuerdo /Dos palomas campesinas /Y en el horizonte, lejos, Se hunde el arcaduz del día. /¡Terrible noria del tiempo!".
pdp:lastStanza.label: last stanza

pdp:lastStanzaOf.comment:
This property points to the Stanza List of which the current Stanza under analysis is its last item.

For example, if we take the poem "Un soneto me manda hacer Violante" by Lope de Vega, the fourth stanza ("Ya estoy en el segundo, y aún sospecho / que voy los trece versos acabando; / contad si son catorce, y está hecho.") is the last stanza.
pdp:lastStanzaOf.label: last stanza of

pdp:lastWord.comment:
This property points to the last Word which form part of a given Line.

For example, "suono" is the last token of the line "Voi ch'ascoltate in rime sparse il suono" from the first sonnet of the "Canzoniere" by Francesco Petrarca.
pdp:lastWord.label: last word

pdp:lastWordOf.comment:
This property points to Line of which the current Word is its last element.

For example, the token "breeding" is the last token of the line "April is the cruellest month, breeding" from the poem "The Waste Land" by T. S. Eliot.
pdp:lastWordOf.label: last word of

pdp:lemma.comment:
A lemma is a Word that stands at the head of a definition in a dictionary. All the head words in a dictionary are lemmas. Technically, it is "a base Word and its inflections".

For example, for the verbal forms "querer", "querremos" and "quería", the lemma is "querer".
pdp:lemma.label: lemma

pdp:line.comment:
Line of a Line List.

For example, the poem "Non chiederci la parola che squadri da ogni lato" by Eugenio Montale has the line "Ah l’uomo che se ne va sicuro,"  as the first line of the second stanza.
pdp:line.label: line

pdp:lineList.comment:
This property refers to the Line List a given Line belongs to.

For example, in the poem "Mientras por competir por tu cabello", the line "en tierra, en humo, en polvo, en sombra, en nada" belongs to the fourth stanza ("no sólo en plata o vïola troncada / se vuelva, mas tú y ello, juntamente, / en tierra, en humo, en polvo, en sombra, en nada.")
pdp:lineList.label: line list

pdp:lineMaxLength.comment: The maximum number of metrical syllables that may occur for a line considering all the metaplasms that provoke a single grammatical syllables to be considered as two metrical ones.

pdp:lineMinLength.comment: The minimum number of metrical syllables that may occur for a line considering all the metaplasms that may join grammatical syllables into metrical ones

pdp:mentions.comment:
Agent or Place that is mentioned on the line

Example: The line from the poem "Piedra negra sobre una piedra blanca" by César Vallejo "Me moriré en París con aguacero," has mention to the Place "Paris"
pdp:mentions.label: mentions

pdp:mentionsAgent.comment:
This property points to the Place that is mentioned in a given Line.

Example: The following line from the Purgatorio of Divina Commedia by Dante Alighieri contains mention to the Agent "Dante": "Dante, perché Virgilio se ne vada"
pdp:mentionsAgent.label: mentions agent

pdp:mentionsPlace.comment:
This property points to the Place that is mentioned in a given Line.

Example: For example, the line "Granada, calle de Elvira," from the poem "Granada" by Federico García Lorca, contains mention to the place "Granada".
pdp:mentionsPlace.label: mentions place

pdp:metricalCategory.comment:
Major category to identify the metrical type (e.g. fixed forms vs strophic).

For example, if we consider the sonnet by Garcilaso "Soneto XVII", metricalCatehory is Strophic.
pdp:metricalCategory.label: metrical category

pdp:metricalComplexity.comment:
Categorisation depending on the number of syllables: usually, less or more than eight.

For example, if we consider the sonnet by Garcilaso "Soneto XVII", metricalComplexity is "verso de arte mayor" because all lines are hendecasyllables.
pdp:metricalComplexity.label: metrical complexity

pdp:metricalContext.comment:
Categorisation depending on whether all lines have the same number of syllables.

For example, if we consider the sonnet by Garcilaso "Soneto XVII", metricalContext is "Isosyllabic" because all lines are hendecasyllables, hence, exhibit the same metrical length.
pdp:metricalContext.label: metrical context

pdp:metricalNotes.comment:
Metrical commentary.

For example, the poem "A creer devemos que todo pecado" contains the following metrical commentary in the Cantigas de Santa María for Singers Database: "Synaeresis, which is common in forms of the verb veer (= "to see"), is required here to reduce viía to two metrical syllables (contrast line 24 where it has its natural three). The compressed syllable vii- benefits from a long note  in the music, however"
pdp:metricalNotes.label: metrical notes

pdp:metricalSymbol.comment:
Symbol use to define a feature in a metrical pattern.

For example, the symbol "+" is used as metricalSymbol of an stressed syllable.
pdp:metricalSymbol.label: metrical symbol

pdp:metricalType.comment:
Categorisation of the stanza/line  grouping or work according to metrics. E.g. “sapphic stanza”.

For example, "By taking as example the poem "La torre de Monterrey a la luz de la luna" by Miguel de Unamuno:  "Torre de Monterrey, \ cuadrada torre, que miras desfilar hombres y días,\ tú me hablas del pasado y del futuro \ Renacimiento.". In this case, metricalType is "sapphic stanza".
pdp:metricalType.label: metrical type

pdp:moraeMetricalScheme.comment:
Metrical scheme according to the number of morae.

For instance, the metrical analysis of the 616th line of the Bacchae by Euripides is: 
(—x. . x.)   (. x. . x.) (. x. . x.)(x. x. . x.) (the transliterated text is "ta ́u.ta ka`ı ka.thu ́b.ris’ au.to ́n ho ́.te me des.meu ́.ein do.ko ́on").
pdp:moraeMetricalScheme.label: morae metrical scheme

pdp:morphologicalAnnotation.comment:
Any type of morphological analysis (from POS to morpheme composition).

For example, for the word "rojos" , the morphological composition is the following: "roj" is the stem, "o" is the inflectional morpheme indicating masculine and "s" in the inflectional morpheme indicating plural.
pdp:morphologicalAnnotation.label: morphological annotation

pdp:nextFoot.comment:
This property points to the next instance of Foot.

For example, if we consider the first foot of the first line of the sonnet I by Shakespeare "From fairest creatures we desire increase", namely |from fai|, nextFoot is |rest crea|
pdp:nextFoot.label: next foot

pdp:nextFootAfterCaesura.comment:
This property points to the next instance of Foot when this is positioned after a caesura.

For example, consider the first line of the sonnet by the Dutch Renaissance poet P.C. Hooft "Leitsterren van mijn hoop, planeten van mijn jeucht". Given that this iambic alexandrine is divided into six feet (noted here as I) and exhibits a caesura (noted here as ||) after the first three feet as follows: |Leitster| ren van| mijn hoop||, plane| ten van| mijn jeucht|. In this case, previousFootBeforeCaesura is "plane".
pdp:nextFootAfterCaesura.label: next foot after caesura

pdp:nextGrammaticalSyllable.comment:
This property points to the Syllable that follows the Syllable under analysis in a Word.

For example, if we consider the syllable "can" in the word "cansado", the next syllable is "sa".
pdp:nextGrammaticalSyllable.label: next grammatical syllable

pdp:nextLine.comment:
This property points to following Line of the Line under analysis in a Line List.

For example, if we consider the line "April is the cruellest most" from the poem "The Waste Land" by T.S. Eliot, "Lilacs out of the dead land, mixing" is the next line.
pdp:nextLine.label: next line

pdp:nextMora.comment:
This property points to the next unit that forms the foot (an instance of FootDivision).

For example, if we consider the unit "rest" of the second foot of the first line of the sonnet I by Shakespeare ("From fairest creatures we desire increase") , namely |rest crea|, nextUnit in the foot is "crea".
pdp:nextMora.label: next mora

pdp:nextPunctuation.comment: This property points to the following Punctuation of a given Punctuation in a Punctuation List.
pdp:nextPunctuation.label: next punctuation

pdp:nextStanza.comment:
This property points to the Stanza that follows the Stanza under analysis in a Stanza List.

For example, in the poem "SONETO XIII" by Garcilaso de la Vega, if we are analysing the first stanza, next stanza would be "De áspera corteza se cubrían / los tiernos miembros que aún bullendo estaban; / los blancos pies en tierra se hincaban, /Y en torcidas raíces se volvían."
pdp:nextStanza.label: next stanza

pdp:nextWord.comment:
This property points to a Word that follows the current Word under analysis in a Line.

For example, if the poem under analysis is "Romance sonámbulo" and we have already analyse the first token ("verde"), next token would be "que".
pdp:nextWord.label: next word

pdp:numberOfFeet.comment:
Number of feet.

If we consider the first line of the first sonnet by Shakespeare, namely "From fairest creatures we desire increase," the numberOfFeet is: 5
pdp:numberOfFeet.label: number of feet

pdp:numberOfGrammaticalSyllables.comment: The exact number of syllables of a Word, that is, without paying attention to any metrical phenomena that may affect the counting
pdp:numberOfGrammaticalSyllables.label: number of grammatical syllables

pdp:numberOfLines.comment:
Number of lines in item.

If we consider the second stanza from the poem "Acaso..." by Antonio Machado:     "Brotaban verdes hojas \ de las hinchadas yemas del ramaje, \ y flores amarillas, blancas, rojas, /\alegraban la mancha del paisaje." numberOFLines is: 4.
pdp:numberOfLines.label: number of lines

pdp:numberOfMorae.comment:
The number of morae the foot contains.

If we consider first dactylic foot of the line 51 from Ovid's Tristia: "Vergilium vidi tantum, nec avara Tibullo" (Vergĭlĭ | um vī | dī tan | tum, nĕc ă | māră Tĭ | bullō), namely "Vergili", numberOfMorae is: 4.
pdp:numberOfMorae.label: number of morae

pdp:numberOfPunctuations.comment: Total number of punctuation in a Punctuation List.

pdp:numberOfStanzas.comment:
Number of stanzas.

"If we consider the poem "Acaso..." by Antonio Machado: "Como atento no más a mi quimera \ no reparaba en torno mío, un día  \ me sorprendió la fértil primavera \ que en todo el ancho campo sonreía. 

Brotaban verdes hojas  \ de las hinchadas \ yemas del ramaje, \ y flores amarillas, blancas, rojas, \ alegraban la mancha del paisaje. 

Y era una lluvia de saetas de oro, \ el sol sobre las frondas juveniles; \ del amplio río en el caudal sonoro \ se miraban los álamos gentiles. 

Tras de tanto camino es la primera \ vez que miro brotar la primavera, \ dije, y después, declamatoriamente: 

¿¡Cuán tarde ya para la dicha mía!? \ Y luego, al caminar, como quien siente \ alas de otra ilusión: Y todavía \ ¡yo alcanzaré mi juventud un día!" Number of stanza is: 5.
pdp:numberOfStanzas.label: number of stanzas

pdp:numberOfWords.comment: The total number of words of a Line
pdp:numberOfWords.label: number of words

pdp:onset.comment:
Sound or sounds occurring before the nucleus, a consonant or consonant cluster.

For example, in the word "mar" in Spanish, the syllable onset is "m".
pdp:onset.label: onset

pdp:paraphrasis.comment:
The recasting of the contents in words different from that originally used, whether in the same language or in a translation.

For example, a possible paraphrasis of the famous first tercet of Dante's "Divina Commedia" is:"A metà del nostro cammino di vita terrena mi trovai in un bosco scuro e buio poiché avevo perso la retta via".
pdp:paraphrasis.label: paraphrasis

pdp:partOfSpeech.comment:
The category or type of a Word. Words in the same category (or, more generally, of lexical items) have similar grammatical properties. Commonly listed  parts of speech are noun, verb, adjective, adverb, pronoun, preposition, conjunction, interjection, and sometimes numeral, article, or determiner. We exclude punctuations from the possible values as we employ the Punctuation class for this purpose

For example, if we take the poem "Autorretrato" by Antonio Machado, the word "infancia" has noun as its Part of Speech.
pdp:partOfSpeech.label: part of speech

pdp:patterningMetricalScheme.comment:
Metrical scheme for quantitative, tonal, accentual or accentual-syllabic metre.

If we consider the line "From fairest creatures we desire increase," from the first sonnet by Shakespeare, patterningMetricalScheme is: -+-+-+-+-+
pdp:patterningMetricalScheme.label: patterning metrical scheme

pdp:phonemePattern.comment:
All phonemes in a line represented by their nearest written equivalents. They could be arranged in alphabetical order to show sound repetitions.

If we take, for example, the line "Si quejas y lamentos pueden tanto," from the sonnet "Si quejas y lamentos puedan tanto" by Garcilaso, the phonemePattern is "aaa d eeee ii k l m nnn oo p sss ttt w x"
pdp:phonemePattern.label: phoneme pattern

pdp:phonemePatternByManner.comment:
All phonemes in a line represented by manner of articulation. They could be arranged in alphabetical order to show sound repetitions. The coding scheme presented in one of the databases stands for the different manners of articulation of consonants, and at the same time groups together front and back vowels.

If we take, for example, the line "Si quejas y lamentos pueden tanto," from the sonnet "Si quejas y lamentos puedan tanto" by Garcilaso, the phonemePatternByManner is: fricative, front vowel, stop, front vowel, fricative, front vowel, fricative, front vowel, liquid, front vowel, stop, front vowel, stop, stop, back vowel, fricative, stop, back vowel, front vowel, fricative, front vowel, nasal, stop, front vowel, stop, stop, back vowel.
pdp:phonemePatternByManner.label: phoneme pattern by manner

pdp:phoneticTranscription.comment:
Phonetic transcription

For example, in the case of the Spanish word "novio", the phonetic transcription is ['nɔ.βjo].
pdp:phoneticTranscription.label: phonetic transcription

pdp:prefinalConsonants.comment:
Consonants between the stressed vowel and the last consonant.

For example, in the rhyme "doliente-accidente" (rhyme between the first and the fourth line) from the sonnet XXXVIII by Fernando de Herrera, the prefinalConsonant is "n".
pdp:prefinalConsonants.label: prefinal consonants

pdp:previousFoot.comment:
This property points to the previous instance of Foot.

For example, if we consider the second foot of the first line of the sonnet I by Shakespeare "From fairest creatures we desire increase", namely |rest crea|, previousFoot is |from fai|
pdp:previousFoot.label: previous foot

pdp:previousFootBeforeCaesura.comment:
This property points to the previous instance of Foot when this is positioned before a caesura.

For example, consider  the first line of the sonnet by the Dutch Renaissance poet P.C. Hooft "Leitsterren van mijn hoop, planeten van mijn jeucht". Given that this iambic alexandrine is divided into six feet (noted here as I) and exhibits a caesura (noted here as ||) after the first three feet as follows: |Leitster| ren van| mijn hoop||, plane| ten van| mijn jeucht|. In this case, previousFootBeforeCaesura is "mijn hoop".
pdp:previousFootBeforeCaesura.label: previous foot before caesura

pdp:previousGrammaticalSyllable.comment:
This property relates a given Syllable to its preceeding Syllable in a Word.

For example, if we consider the syllable "lor" in the word "color", "previousSyllable" is "co".
pdp:previousGrammaticalSyllable.label: previous grammatical syllable

pdp:previousLine.comment:
This property points to the previous item of a list that contains an instance of Line.

For example, "Aunque es verdad que he escrito algunos miles" is the previous line of the line "de versos, si no buenos, tales cuales" of the poem "Aunque es verdad" by Tomás de Iriarte.
pdp:previousLine.label: previous line

pdp:previousMora.comment:
This property points to the previous unit that forms the foot (an instance of FootDivision).

For example, if we consider the unit "crea" of the second foot of the first line of the sonnet I by Shakespeare ("From fairest creatures we desire increase") , namely |rest crea|, previousUnit in the foot is "rest".
pdp:previousMora.label: previous mora

pdp:previousPunctuation.comment: This property points to the preceeding Punctuation of a Punctuation List.
pdp:previousPunctuation.label: previous punctuation

pdp:previousStanza.comment:
This property points to previous Stanza of the Stanza under analysis in a Stanza List.

For example, in the poem "Why I Am Not A Painter" by Frank O'Hara, previous stanza to the second one is the first ("I am not a painter. I am a poet / Why? I think I would rather be / a painter, but I am not. Well,")
pdp:previousStanza.label: previous stanza

pdp:previousWord.comment:
This property relates a given Word to its preceeding Word in a Line.

For example, if we consider the token "month", the line "April is the cruellest month, breeding" from the poem "The Waste Land" by T. S. Eliot, the previous token is "cruellest".
pdp:previousWord.label: previous word

pdp:punctuation.comment: This property points to a Punctuation that is contained in a given Punctuation List.
pdp:punctuation.label: punctuation

pdp:punctuationList.comment: This property refers to the Punctuation List that a Punctuation belongs to.
pdp:punctuationList.label: punctuation list

pdp:punctuationNumber.label: The position of a Punctuation in a Punctuation List.

pdp:relativeLineNumber.comment: Index of a Line (verse) in the Stanza it belongs to.
pdp:relativeLineNumber.label: relative line number

pdp:rhetoricalOperation.comment: Classification categories of speech figures in relation to rhetorical operations: addition, omission, transposition and permutation
pdp:rhetoricalOperation.label: rethorical operation

pdp:rhymeDispositionType.comment:
Categorisation of the stanza according to the diposition of the rhymes (eg. “cross”, “pair”).

For example, if we consider the first stanza of the sonnet XXIII by Garcilaso: "En tanto que de rosa y de azucena\ se muestra la color en vuestro gesto,\ y que vuestro mirar ardiente, honesto,\con clara luz la tempestad serena;" rhymeDisposition is "enclosed".
pdp:rhymeDispositionType.label: rhyme disposition type

pdp:rhymeGrapheme.comment:
Grapheme that represents the rhyming sounds.

If we consider, as an example, the rhyme "infinito-frito" in the poem by Quevedo "A un hombre de gran nariz", rhyme grapheme is "ito".
pdp:rhymeGrapheme.label: rhyme grapheme

pdp:rhymeLabel.comment:
String used to identify the item at hand (usually, “a”, “b”, “c”, etc.).

For instance, "A" is the label used to mark the rhyme between the first and fourth line of the first stanza of the sonnet III from Petrarcha's "Canzoniere", namely "Era il giorno ch’al sol si scoloraro/ [...] /ché i be’ vostr’occhi, donna, mi legaro.".
pdp:rhymeLabel.label: rhyme label

pdp:rhymePhoneme.comment:
Phonetic transcription of the rhyming sounds.

For instance, if we consider the rhyme "strife-life" from the 55th Psalm by Mary Alcock, rhymePhoneme is /aɪf/.
pdp:rhymePhoneme.label: rhyme phoneme

pdp:rhymeScheme.comment:
A rhyme scheme is the pattern of rhymes at the end of each line of a poem or song. It is usually referred to by using letters to indicate which lines rhyme; lines designated with the same letter all rhyme with each other.

If we consider the first stanza of the sonnet III from Petrarcha's "Canzoniere", namely "Era il giorno ch’al sol si scoloraro / per la pietà del suo factore i rai, / quando i’ fui preso, et non me ne guardai, /ché i be’ vostr’occhi, donna, mi legaro.". rhymeScheme is: "ABBA".
pdp:rhymeScheme.label: rhyme scheme

pdp:rhymeTypeProportion.comment:
Proportion of the feminine/masculine rhymes of the poem.

If we consider, as an example, the sonnet I by Shakespeare, all rhymes are masculine rhymes: "From fairest creatures we desire increase,/ That thereby beauty's rose might never die, /But as the riper should by time decease, /His tender heir might bear his memory:/ But thou contracted to thine own bright eyes,/ Feed'st thy light's flame with self-substantial fuel,/ Making a famine where abundance lies,/ Thy self thy foe, to thy sweet self too cruel:/ Thou that art now the world's fresh ornament,/ And only herald to the gaudy spring,/ Within thine own bud buriest thy content,/ And, tender churl, mak'st waste in niggarding:/  Pity the world, or else this glutton be,/ To eat the world's due, by the grave and thee.". Consequently, the rhymeTypeProportion will be "100% masculine rhymes".
pdp:rhymeTypeProportion.label: rhyme type proportion

pdp:rhymesWith.comment:
This property points to an instance of Line that rhymes with the current Line under analysis.

For example, if we consider the line in the sonnet III from Petrarch's "Canzoniere", "Era il giorno ch’al sol si scoloraro", rhymesWith is the line "ché i be' vostr'occhi, Donna, mi legaro".
pdp:rhymesWith.label: rhymes with

pdp:scannedLine.comment:
A line metrically analysed, marked up in terms of syllable division and accent.

If we consider, as an example, the line "From fairest creatures we desire increase," from the first sonnet by Shakespeare, scannedLine is "from FAI.|rest. CREA.|tures. WE.| de.SIRE.| in.CREASE."
pdp:scannedLine.label: scanned line

pdp:scheme.comment:
Abstraction that represents the outline of the unit through a pattern. E.g. “ox(o)“ to represent the type of syllables.

If we consider, as an example, the fist foot of  the line "From fairest creatures we desire increase," from the first sonnet by Shakespeare, namely |From fai|, scheme is "-+".
pdp:scheme.label: scheme

pdp:secondHemistich.comment:
This property points to the second division of the line (an instance of Line) that forms the second hemistich.

For example, if we consider the line "Sous le flambeau d’Amour, des éternelles nuits" from the sonnet "Afin que pour jamais une marque demeure" by Jean Antoine de Baïf, the "secondHemistich" is the line "des éternelles nuits".
pdp:secondHemistich.label: second hemistich

pdp:stanza.comment:
Stanza associated with the Stanza List that breaks down a Redaction.

For instance, the redaction of Divina Commedia edited by Raffaele Andreoli published by Barbèra Editore, Florence, in 1879, has the stanza "Veramente, però ch'a questo segno/ Molto si mira e poco si discerne,/Dirò perchè tal modo fu più degno."
pdp:stanza.label: stanza

pdp:stanzaList.comment:
This property refers to the Stanza List that a Stanza belongs to.

For example, the line "veo llegar la corta vida mía" from the poem "A la pequeña luz del breve dia" by Fernando de Herrera belongs to the Redaction of the poem in Algunas obras (1582).
pdp:stanzaList.label: stanza list

pdp:stanzaNumber.comment:
Position of the Stanza inside the Redaction.

For example, if we take the first stanza of the Sonnet XIII by Garcilaso de la Vega, that is "A Dafne ya los brazos le crecían, / y en luengos ramos vueltos se mostraban; / en verdes hojas vi que se tornaban / los cabellos que'l oro escurecían", the position of this stanza inside the Redaction is 1.
pdp:stanzaNumber.label: stanza number

pdp:stressPosition.comment:
Position of the stressed syllable from the end of the word.ç

If we take, for instance, the word "esperanza", stressPosition is 2, because stress in on the second syllable of the word.
pdp:stressPosition.label: stress position

pdp:syllabicMetricalLength.comment:
Metrical scheme according to the number of syllables.

For instance, if we consider the line "From fairest creatures we desire increase," from the first sonnet by Shakespeare and analyse them only in terms of number of syllables, syllabicMetricalScheme is: 10 syllables.
pdp:syllabicMetricalLength.label: syllabic metrical length

pdp:symbolExplanation.comment:
Meaning of the symbol used in a metrical pattern.

In the metrical pattern description of the line he line "From fairest creatures we desire increase," from the first sonnet by Shakespeare, that is -+-+-+-+-+, + indicates stressed syllables and - unstressed syllables.
pdp:symbolExplanation.label: symbol explanation

pdp:translation.comment:
Translation of a Word

For instance, if we take the Spanish word "viaje" the English translation would be "journey".
pdp:translation.label: translation

pdp:typeOfIntertextuality.comment: Categorisation of the work under analysis depending on the relationship between this work and other texts. E.g. “contrafactum”, “de seguir”, etc.
pdp:typeOfIntertextuality.label: type of intertextuality

pdp:typeOfMetaplasm.comment:
Type of Metaplasm.

For example, if we consider the two words "sparse il" in the line from the sonnet I from the Canzoniere by Petrarca, namely "Voi ch'ascoltate in rime sparse il suono", the typeOfMetaplasm taking place across the two words is "synaloepha".
pdp:typeOfMetaplasm.label: type of metaplasm

pdp:typeOfNucleus.comment:
Type of syllabic nucleus (linguistic typology).

For example, if we consider the first syllable of the word "boca" (i.e. "bo"), "nucleusType" is "vowel".
pdp:typeOfNucleus.label: type of nucleus

pdp:typeOfRhymeMatching.comment:
Explain the degree in which the different rhyming sounds match (e.g. assonant, consonant, perfect, imperfect, half-rhyme...).

For example, if we consider the rhyme "scoloraro-legaro" in the sonnet III from Petrarch's "Canzoniere", typeofRhymeMatching is "perfect rhyme". See the example lines:  "Era il giorno ch’al sol si scoloraro \ per la pietà del suo factore i rai,\ quando i' fui preso, et non me ne guardai, \ché i be' vostr'occhi, Donna, mi legaro".
pdp:typeOfRhymeMatching.label: type of rhyme matching

pdp:typeOfScansion.comment: Specifies if the annotation is manual or automatic.

pdp:typeOfStanza.comment:
Type of Stanza, but not in relation to its metrics. E.g. tornada, refrain.

For instance, the stanza "Bailada, ten ta carrera/ e digues a la tan bella/ que heu m' i seray en breu" from the anonymous poem "Na dolça res, be m’es greu" is a "tornada".
pdp:typeOfStanza.label: type of stanza

pdp:typeOfStanzaEdition.comment:
The type of the text provided in the Stanza. 
Eg.: Diplomatic edition, critical edition, translation

For instance, if we consider the first stanza of the Inferno of the Divina Commedia (i.e. "Nel mezzo del cammin di nostra vita/ mi ritrovai per una selva oscura/ ché la diritta via era smarrita.") from the critical edition "La Divina Commedia. Inferno" edited by A.M. Chiavacci Leonardi, the type of Stanza Edition will be "critical edition".
pdp:typeOfStanzaEdition.label: type of stanza edition

pdp:usedAsRedaction.comment: This property points to the text under analysis (Redaction) which has been a source for the current cultural product
pdp:usedAsRedaction.label: used as redaction

pdp:usesAsSource.comment: This property points to a cultural product (Intertextuality) which was a source for the work under analysis
pdp:usesAsSource.label: used as source

pdp:usesEncoding.comment:
This property points to the instance of MetricalEncoding in which the conventions implemented in the item at hand are explained.

For example, in the poem "Amadís de Gaula a don Quijote de La Mancha", the presented metrical Pattern uses the following MetricalEncoding: the symbol "+" for stressed syllables and the symbol "-" for unstressed ones.
pdp:usesEncoding.label: uses encoding

pdp:versificationType.comment:
Type of metre: accentual verse, accentual-syllabic verse, syllabic verse, quantitative verse, etc.

For example, if we consider the sonnet I from "L'olive" by Du Bellay, versificationType is "syllabic verse" because its type of versification is based on the number of syllables per line only.
pdp:versificationType.label: versification type

pdp:vowelTypeScheme.comment:
Linguistic properties of the vowels of the line.

If we consider, for instance, the line "Morir soñando, sí, mas si se sueña" from the poem "Morir soñando" by Unamuno, vowelTypeScheme is: monophthong back close-mid, monophthong front close, monophthong back close-mid, monophthong front open, monophthong back close-mid, monophthong front close, monophthong front open, monophthong front close, monophthong front close-mid, diphthong labio-velar approximant + front close-mid vowel, monophthong front open.
pdp:vowelTypeScheme.label: vowel type scheme

pdp:weight.comment:
Pattern according to the number and/or duration of segments in the syllabic rime, that is, the nucleus and coda.

For example, in Latin the first syllable of the word 'Arma' (i.e. 'ar') is heavy because it contains a short vowel followed by a consonant. In English the word "cat" constitutes a heavy syllable.
pdp:weight.label: weight

pdp:word.comment:
Word of a Line.

For example, the line "Bruscamente la tarde se ha aclarado" from the poem "La lluvia" by Jorge Luis Borges, has "bruscamente" as a token.
pdp:word.label: word

pdp:wordList.comment:
This property refers to the Line that contains a given Word.

For example, the token "April" belongs to the line "April is the cruellest month, breeding" from the poem "The Waste Land" by T. S. Eliot.
pdp:wordList.label: word list

pdp:wordNumber.comment:
Position of the Word within the Line to which it belongs.

For example, if we take the last line of the poem "Canary" by Rita Dove, the word "mystery" has the position 8 in the line.
pdp:wordNumber.label: word number

pdp:wordSense.comment:
One of the meanings of a word or phrase.

For example, in the poem "Suspiro y pruebo con la voz doliente" by Fernando de Herrera, the sense of the word “suspiro” is, according to the Diccionario de la Real Academia Española (the Dictionary of the Royal Spanish Academy), “Dar suspiros” (sigh).
pdp:wordSense.label: word sense

pdt:BibliographicSource.comment:
A Bibliographic Source is a conceptual entity representing bibliographic products that are generated following a publication process. Instances of pdt:BibliographicSource represent the ideal physical properties of all the exemplars. Despite Bibliographic Sources are not physical objects per se (are not accessible), they encapsulate design properties of the physical carriers (layout, pages, desired material, etc.) and hence they can be "physically" described.

An object of type pdt:BibliographicSource embodies one or more textual editions (instances of pdc:Redaction). They mostly represent books that may gather several redactions or poems. In order to represent all the physical copies of the ideal manifestation, we associate this kind of source with instances of pdt:Item.

pdt:BibliographicSource is then considered an E73 Informatio Object, which is subclass of E90 Symbolic Object which represents conceptual objects subjected to rights and ownership. Instances of pdt:Item are aligned to E84 Information Carrier.
pdt:BibliographicSource.label: Bibliographic Source

pdt:CarrierProduction.comment:
Instances of pdt:CarrierProduction describe the activity performed by some agent when giving rise to a physical carrier for a textual edition of a poem.

A Carrier Production has a set of pdc:AgentRole structures associated indicating the actors and the roles they performed during the participation in the event. The Carrier Production is then carried by taking a textual edition as input (an instance of pdc:Redaction) and generates an Information Carrier (an instance of pdt:InformationCarrier)

As a Carrier Production is an activity with input and output objects and participants, it is a subclass of E7 Activity. In addition, being it a type of event involving the creation of a carrier, it is also subclass of E63 Beginning of Existence.
pdt:CarrierProduction.label: Carrier Production

pdt:Condition.comment:
A Condition is a state of a physical edition of a poem subjected to a period or time span. Hence, instances of pdt:Condition are related to pdt:InformationCarrier and pdc:TimeSpan.

pdt:Condition is aligned with CIDOC CRM E3 Condition State.

pdt:OWLClassImpl_8fa2b552_0357_457f_bab1.comment:
A pdt:Collection is an aggregation of instances of pdt:InformationCarrier that are curated and preserved by some pdc:Agent.

A Collection can be a set of physical manuscripts or exemplars (i.e. a corpus, a personal collection of books). For example, "Gongocorpus" is a pdt:Collection that collects physical electronic editions of Gongora's Poems.

Being a collection a physical aggregation, it has been aligned as a subclass of CIDOC CRM E78 Collection
pdt:OWLClassImpl_8fa2b552_0357_457f_bab1.label: Collection

pdt:Reproduction.comment:
A Reproduction is an activity in which some actor performs a copy of a physical edition to produce a facsimile. A reproduction of a facsimile is also another facsimile. 

Instances of pdt:Reproduction have agent-role structures associated (pdc:AgentRole) to indicate the type of role performed by an actor during the reproduction. Reproductions are associated to the carrier being reproduced (of type pdt:InformationCarrier) and generate the copy (instance of pdt:Facsimile) following a specific technique.

pdt:Reproduction is aligned to E7 Activity and to E63 Beginning of Existence to indicate that it has input/output objects and it gices rise to a new object.
pdt:Reproduction.label: Reproduction

pdt:conditionType.comment: Ex: Burned pages, highligthed text, included notes, etc.

prisms:Annotation.comment: A cnt:Content-equivalent class holding a W3C Annotation Model annotation (free-text), serialized in JSON format.
prisms:Annotation.label: Annotation

prisms:Bookmark.comment: A cnt:Content-equivalent class holding a PRISMS bookmark of an object, serialized in JSON.
prisms:Bookmark.label: Bookmark

prisms:NamedEntityReference.comment: A cnt:Content-equivalent class holding a W3C Annotation Model annotation (a named entity reference), serialized in JSON format.
prisms:NamedEntityReference.label: Named Entity Reference

prisms:Notebook.comment: A cnt:Content-equivalent class holding a notebook in Editor.js-format, serialized in JSON.
prisms:Notebook.label: Notebook

prisms:Relation.comment: A cnt:Content-equivalent class holding a W3C Annotation Model annotation (relation), serialized in JSON format.
prisms:Relation.label: Relation

prisms:Workbench.comment: A cnt:Content-equivalent class holding a PRISMS workbench snapshot (objects and components), serialized in JSON.
prisms:Workbench.label: Workbench

prisms:hasStartPage.comment: This property associates a crmdig:D9_Data_Object representing an imageset (facsimile) with an rdfs:Literal indicating the starting page in the page sequence provided by the imageset.
prisms:hasStartPage.label: has start page

prisms:isFreeImageSet.comment: This property associates a crmdig:D1_Digital_Object, an aggregation of digital objects representing a digital manifestation, with a crmdig:D9_Data_Object representing a freely-accessible imageset (facsimile) as one of the components of the aggregation.
prisms:isFreeImageSet.label: has a free image set

prisms:restricted.comment: A crm:E55_Type of access level classification, indicating access is 'restricted', and may require permissions provided by policies, credentials, memberships, or other forms of authorization.
prisms:restricted.label: restricted

prisms:unavailable.comment: A crm:E55_Type of access level classification, indicating access is 'unavailable', and cannot be achieved through permissions provided by policies, credentials, memberships, or other forms of authorization.
prisms:unavailable.label: unavailable

skos:broader.comment: Broader concepts are typically rendered as parents in a concept hierarchy (tree).
skos:broader.label: has broader

skos:exactMatch.comment: skos:exactMatch is disjoint with each of the properties skos:broadMatch and skos:relatedMatch.
skos:exactMatch.label: has exact match

skos:mappingRelation.comment: These concept mapping relations mirror semantic relations, and the data model defined below is similar (with the exception of skos:exactMatch) to the data model defined for semantic relations. A distinct vocabulary is provided for concept mapping relations, to provide a convenient way to differentiate links within a concept scheme from links between concept schemes. However, this pattern of usage is not a formal requirement of the SKOS data model, and relies on informal definitions of best practice.
skos:mappingRelation.label: is in mapping relation with

skos:narrower.comment: Narrower concepts are typically rendered as children in a concept hierarchy (tree).
skos:narrower.label: has narrower
